author: By Char Adams
title: It’s OK to Feel OK Right Now
description: Even amid all of the suffering, give yourself permission to be OK.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic began to spread, I expected it to upend my life. As a Black disabled woman living in New York, once the American epicenter of the crisis, I thought I would bear the brunt of whatever was about to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Ali Smith’s ‘Summer’ Ends a Funny, Political, Very Up-to-Date Quartet
description: Smith’s series of seasonal novels has kept pace with the world’s news, and now she brings it to a close with the arrival of Covid-19.
content: A favorite bit of advice about writing criticism is from Anthony Lane, in the introduction to his collection “Nobody’s Perfect.” It’s just five words: “Never read the publicity material.” The problem, he writes, is that the provided synopses deliver “a false impression of coherence.” My corollary to Lane’s maxim would be: “Even dust jackets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.7 Million Homes in California
description: A 1935 storybook house in Palo Alto, a midcentury-modern home in Los Angeles and an 1895 Mission Revival-style retreat in Santa Barbara.
content: Built in the storybook style popular in California in the 1930s, this house was expanded in the 1970s. but retains a number of original details, including a small wrought-iron squirrel attached to a chimney support on the roof, an arched front door with iron strapping and exposed ceiling beams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why We Cover What Politicians Wear
description: For both men and women, clothes can be an important tool for communication. Often, there’s strategy behind the style.
content: Ever since Kamala Harris was announced as Joe Biden’s choice for vice president, making her the first Black woman and the first person of Indian descent to be nominated for national office by a major party, celebrations of the historic moment have ensued. So too have the related moans about how, because she is a woman, her clothes will be used to diminish and define her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump, the Mail and the Unbinding of America
description: The Postal Service facilitates citizen inclusion. That’s why Trump hates it.
content: In June the independent website Factcheck.org made a dig at Joe Biden, publishing a post titled “Biden Floats Baseless Election Conspiracy.” Biden, you see, had suggested that Donald Trump “wants to cut off money for the post office so they cannot deliver mail-in ballots.” There was, said the post, no evidence that Trump’s “stance toward the U.S. postal system is related to the presidential election.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Guggenheim Approves Diversity Plan After Staff Complaints of Racism
description: An expansive effort comes as the museum faces a deficit of $15 million.
content: The Guggenheim Museum has approved a plan to address complaints of entrenched racism within its walls. It is one of the first major cultural organizations to provide details of an expanded diversity effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Defying Trump, 5 Automakers Lock In a Deal on Greenhouse Gas Pollution
description: The five — Ford, Honda, BMW, Volkswagen and Volvo — sealed a binding agreement with California to follow the state’s stricter tailpipe emissions rules.
content: WASHINGTON — California on Monday finalized a legal settlement with five of the world’s largest automakers that binds them to comply with its stringent state-level fuel efficiency standards that would cut down on climate-warming tailpipe emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: A Big Ol’ Virtual Experiment
description: Here’s what we’re watching as the Democrats begin their week of nightly Zoom addresses.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry L. Schwartz
title: Quiet Reflections on the Enchanting Italian Village of Panicale
description: Pensive after the loss of a friend, a photographer finds solace — and instruction — on a trip to the central Italian region of Umbria.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Barry L. Schwartz shares a collection of images from the central Italian region of Umbria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León and John Schwartz
title: Death Valley Just Recorded the Hottest Temperature on Earth
description: Scientists still have to validate the reading of 130 degrees Fahrenheit on Sunday, the equivalent of 54 degrees Celsius.
content: In the popular imagination, Death Valley in Southern California is the hottest place on earth. At 3:41 p.m. on Sunday, it lived up to that reputation when the temperature at the aptly named Furnace Creek reached 130 degrees Fahrenheit, according to the NOAA Weather Prediction center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump, in Minneapolis, claims Biden and Harris would bring ‘left-wing war on cops’ to the White House.
description: Standing in front of Air Force One on the tarmac of the Minneapolis airport Monday afternoon, President Trump assailed Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris, accusing them of wanting to bring a “left-wing war on cops” to the White House.
content: Standing in front of Air Force One on the tarmac of the Minneapolis airport Monday afternoon, President Trump assailed Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris, accusing them of wanting to bring a “left-wing war on cops” to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Postal Crisis: ‘Our Democracy Is at Risk’
description: Readers criticize President Trump’s efforts to undermine the Postal Service, putting people who rely on it for lifesaving drugs at risk, and suggest ways to save it.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Bernie Sanders Lost Again, but This Time He’ll Deliver a Victory Speech
description: Progressive candidates are winning. The pandemic increased support for “Medicare for all.” What does Mr. Sanders make of it? “He may feel a little bit like Moses.”
content: Bernie Sanders, stoop-shouldered in his navy-blue suit jacket, adjusted his chair and stared into the camera as the livestream began this month. He bobbed and jabbed both fists in the air, verklempt. He smiled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: What to Watch: The First Night of the 2020 Democratic National Convention
description: Michelle Obama will appear, and Democrats will see whether there’s an anti-Trump consensus or a mishmash of messaging, with speakers ranging ideologically from Bernie Sanders to John Kasich.
content: [Speakers, start time, schedule and more: Here’s how to watch the Democratic National Convention.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: How Mail-In Voting Works
description: Voting by mail has been a part of American elections for over a century, and experts say the president’s allegations of widespread fraud are unfounded.
content: More Americans than ever before can vote by mail this year, as states prepare to hold an election under the conditions of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: This year’s conventions, brought to you by the I.T. department.
description: A political convention is traditionally the work of thousands — event planners, camera operators, stage managers, even an inflation team for the ceremonial balloon drop on the nominee.
content: A political convention is traditionally the work of thousands — event planners, camera operators, stage managers, even an inflation team for the ceremonial balloon drop on the nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: They Claimed Covid-19 Cost Them Their Jobs. There Was an Easier Explanation.
description: Twenty-one inmates in the San Mateo County, Calif., jail filed for pandemic unemployment assistance, resulting in payments of at least $250,000, according to the district attorney.
content: Like millions of others across California, more than 20 people living together in San Mateo filed for pandemic unemployment assistance recently, claiming the coronavirus had put them out of work. But according to the authorities, there was a different reason these people were unemployed: They were in the San Mateo Maguire Correctional Facility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall, Mihir Zaveri and Alan Feuer
title: 2 Are Charged in Killing of Jam Master Jay, Hip-Hop Pioneer
description: The two men had long been suspects in the 2002 killing of the D.J., a member of the group Run-DMC.
content: When Jam Master Jay, the D.J. for the pioneering rap group Run DMC, was killed in his studio in Queens nearly 20 years ago, it struck the hip-hop world with the force of a tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Kamala Harris Cartoon in Murdoch Paper Is Denounced as Racist
description: Kevin Rudd, a former prime minister, lodged a complaint against The Australian for publishing material he called “racist and sexist.”
content: PERTH, Australia — A former Australian prime minister has joined the chorus of criticism about a cartoon depiction of Senator Kamala Harris in a Rupert Murdoch-owned national newspaper in Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Despite his defeat, Bernie Sanders will deliver a sort of victory speech tonight.
description: In the months since Senator Bernie Sanders ended his campaign for president, progressive candidates have notched once-improbable primary victories against longtime Democratic incumbents. Each member of the so-called Squad, the group of progressive women of color in the House, will almost certainly return to Washington. The coronavirus pandemic has revitalized support nationwide for progressive policy proposals including “Medicare for all.”
content: In the months since Senator Bernie Sanders ended his campaign for president, progressive candidates have notched once-improbable primary victories against longtime Democratic incumbents. Each member of the so-called Squad, the group of progressive women of color in the House, will almost certainly return to Washington. The coronavirus pandemic has revitalized support nationwide for progressive policy proposals including “Medicare for all.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Critics pile on an S.E.C. proposal to limit investor disclosure
description: In the weeks since the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission announced plans to effectively reduce institutional investors’ public disclosure of their holdings, more than 1,500 people have submitted comments to the commission. The overwhelming majority are opposed to the proposal.
content: In the weeks since the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission announced plans to effectively reduce institutional investors’ public disclosure of their holdings, more than 1,500 people have submitted comments to the commission. The overwhelming majority are opposed to the proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How Children’s Sleep Habits Have Changed in the Pandemic
description: Spending more time on screens, staying up late and sleeping late may require some adjustments for the start of the school year.
content: So how are you sleeping these days? Some children — and adolescents — may actually be getting more sleep, or better sleep, while others are struggling with disrupted routines, anxiety and electronics, sometimes all at the same time. And even for those who have settled into new schedules that leave them reasonably well rested, back-to-school season may mean a possibly problematic reset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Gretchen Whitmer on the Biden Veepstakes and How He Can Win Michigan
description: Ms. Whitmer, the governor of Michigan and a contender on Joe Biden’s short list for V.P., spoke with The Times ahead of her speech on Monday night at the Democratic National Convention.
content: WEST BLOOMFIELD, Mich. — When Gov. Gretchen Whitmer joined Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign in early March as a national chair, she was prepared to help him in the rigorous search for a running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Smollett Case: Special Prosecutor Finds ‘Abuses of Discretion’
description: An investigation has found that the state’s attorney’s office did not violate the law in its handling of the case against the actor Jussie Smollett, but it cited substantial “operational failures.”
content: A special prosecutor tasked with reinvestigating the case against Jussie Smollett has found that the Cook County state’s attorney’s office did not violate the law in its handling of the case but did abuse its discretion in deciding to drop charges and put out false or misleading public statements about why it did so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Will the Virus Resurge in N.Y.C.?
description: The coronavirus has been kept under control in the the state, but it might just be a matter of time before a resurgence.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Washington Hires Former Player as N.F.L.’s First Black Team President
description: Jason Wright, 38, who played seven years in the league before becoming a business consultant, will join the Washington Football Team as it continues an overhaul and rebranding.
content: Jason Wright, a former N.F.L. running back turned business consultant, has been named the new president of the Washington Football Team, the team announced on Monday. He is the first African-American to hold such a position in league history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: One Mask Rule Most New Yorkers Ignore
description: Restaurant diners are supposed to wear facial coverings except when eating or drinking. Hardly anyone does.
content: In the early weeks of the pandemic, when we had to make our own masks or go without, a friend sewed pleats into a soothing blue-and-white rectangle of cotton with ties at the corners and gave them away. I still wear mine, even though many New Yorkers have moved on to the style with elastics that loop behind the ears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Michelle Obama will anchor Monday’s convention program.
description: Back in 2012, President Barack Obama’s advisers routinely referred to Michelle Obama as “the most popular” political figure in the country — and many thought her rousing and resonant speech at the Democratic convention in Charlotte that year was the apex of that very non-virtual event.
content: Back in 2012, President Barack Obama’s advisers routinely referred to Michelle Obama as “the most popular” political figure in the country — and many thought her rousing and resonant speech at the Democratic convention in Charlotte that year was the apex of that very non-virtual event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Amy Schumer Learns to Cook’ and ‘Jawbreaker’
description: The comedian’s culinary apprenticeship continues with a new self-shot season. And a cult classic starring Rose McGowan arrives on Shudder.
content: AMY SCHUMER LEARNS TO COOK 10 p.m. on Food Network. Many of us took to the culinary arts when restaurants began to shut down in the United States in March. The comedian and actress Amy Schumer went one step further, filming her forays into cooking and sharing them with the world. Schumer’s husband, Chris Fischer, a chef, is her guide in the home kitchen. During the first batch of episodes they made latkes, panzanella salad, fish tacos and other dishes that amateurs can try to tackle. They also bantered, shared relationship advice and offered a peek into their personal lives, with their baby, Gene, their nanny, Jane, and their dog, Tatiana, all making appearances. The second season begins tonight with an episode about how to make homemade versions of frozen food favorites and children’s meals that will also appeal to adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Belarus Protests, Greece Migrants, Christophe Girard: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Schools Reopening: The State of Play for K-12
description: This year is anything but typical, and individual districts have been largely left to chart their own paths.
content: In a typical year, nearly two-thirds of the nation’s 50 million public schoolchildren have returned to their classrooms by the third week of August. But this year is anything but typical, with many of the nation’s largest districts delaying the start of school or choosing to open remotely as coronavirus cases surge through their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: With ‘Nobody Going to Work,’ Private Bus Companies Are Worried About the Future
description: One company has suspended all operations for the first time in 150 years. Others have drastically reduced service and are pleading for financial help from the federal government.
content: No other city in America is as reliant on mass transit as New York, with millions of daily riders usually cramming into subway cars, trains and buses run by sprawling public agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: On Being a Biden Conservative
description: It’s about upholding your principles at the expense of your politics.
content: The other day I spotted a sticker that read, “Settle for Biden, 2020.” It spoke for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The UVEA is the middle layer of the eye. It lies under the sclera, or the white part of the eye. The iris, the ciliary body and the choroid make up the UVEA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Are Mammograms Worthwhile for Older Women?
description: Some might be better off not knowing they have breast cancer because they are likely to die of other causes long before breast cancer would threaten their health.
content: The shutdowns and fears provoked by the Covid-19 pandemic threw a monkey wrench into many aspects of routine medical care, especially for older people justifiably wary about being exposed to the virus in a medical setting. While many facilities have now created “safe spaces” to resume in-person exams, some of the resulting postponements of routine checkups can have a major impact on the severity of an undetected or untreated disease and sometimes even the chances of survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph P. Fried
title: Claire Shulman, First Woman to Lead Queens, Dies at 94
description: She became borough president in the wake of a corruption scandal in 1986, then won elections that kept her in office as an advocate for Queens for 16 years.
content: Claire Shulman, who became the first woman to rise to Queens borough president, taking office when her predecessor and boss resigned in a corruption scandal, then won election after election over 16 years as she sought to restore the office’s integrity, died on Sunday at her home in Beechhurst, Queens. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina
title: The ‘Rage Moms’ Democrats Are Counting On
description: As millions of American families face an uncertain start to the school year, the anger of women who find themselves expected to be teacher, caregiver, employee and parent is fueling a political uprising.
content: President Bill Clinton introduced America to the “soccer mom,” anxiously shuttling her children across swing state suburbs in her minivan. President George W. Bush’s re-election campaign found another cutesy moniker, dubbing those voters worried about terrorism after the attacks of Sept. 11 “security moms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: With Another Slew of Injuries, the Yankees Aren’t Taking Chances
description: Aaron Judge, D.J. LeMahieu and Giancarlo Stanton are all on the injured list. Even in a shortened season, the Yankees aren’t rushing to bring them back.
content: Stop us if you’ve heard this before: The Yankees have one of the best records in Major League Baseball despite missing several star players to injury.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ex-State Dept. Aides: Defending Susan Rice’s Record on Africa
description: Four former assistant secretaries of state for African affairs respond to Bret Stephens’s criticism of Ms. Rice.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Coronavirus Doctors Battle Another Scourge: Misinformation
description: Physicians say they regularly treat people more inclined to believe what they read on Facebook than what a medical professional tells them.
content: An emergency room doctor in Illinois was accused in April of profiting from naming coronavirus as the cause of a patient’s death, a rumor spreading online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Felix Joehnk and Matt Wheeler
title: ‘You Have Awakened a Sleeping Giant’
description: A new generation of activists in Thailand is moving away from coded criticism of the military and the monarchy, and publicly calling for wholesale democratic reform.
content: BANGKOK — One student’s sign at the protest read, “No god, no kings, only man.” Another’s said, “You have awakened a sleeping giant.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: New Zealand Election, Japan’s Economy, Belarus: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Four Home Runs in a Row? It’s Not as Rare as It Once Was
description: The White Sox went back-to-back-to-back-to-back on Sunday, the third time it has been done in the last four seasons.
content: Back-to-back home runs are always exciting. And lucky fans sometimes get to see back-to-back-to-back homers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Mail-in voters sue Trump and DeJoy to block cuts at the Postal Service ahead of the election.
description: Mail-in voters from six states filed a lawsuit Monday against President Trump and Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, seeking to block cuts to the Postal Service ahead of the November election.
content: Mail-in voters from six states filed a lawsuit Monday against President Trump and Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, seeking to block cuts to the Postal Service ahead of the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Christina Morales
title: Texas Man Surrenders to Police, Ending 16-Hour Standoff
description: Three police officers were injured in a shooting that began the standoff, the authorities in Cedar Park, Texas, said.
content: A standoff between the police and a man barricaded in a house with three relatives ended early Monday in Cedar Park, Texas, after 16 hours of negotiations and a shooting that injured three officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Nubya Garcia, Tapping Into the Past to Make Jazz for a New Generation
description: The British saxophonist has made a big impact on London’s buzzing scene. Now she’s releasing her first full-length album, “Source.”
content: It hasn’t taken long for the 28-year-old tenor saxophonist Nubya Garcia to make a big impression in the acclaimed British jazz scene she came up in, and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kay Nolan and Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Questions Biden’s Mental Abilities and Calls Harris Biden’s ‘Boss’
description: The president made three campaign rally-like appearances at airports in Minnesota and Wisconsin in an attempt to counterprogram the first night of the Democratic National Convention.
content: OSHKOSH, Wis. — President Trump questioned former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s mental capabilities and mocked Senator Kamala Harris of California as an extreme liberal in three campaign rally-like appearances on Monday as Democrats began their four-day national political convention nominally in Milwaukee but largely online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Hoover Greenway
title: How to Protect Children’s Eyes During Remote Learning
description: You can preserve your kids’ vision even as screen-time becomes a bigger part of their lives. No special glasses required.
content: With many school districts reopening this fall with fully remote or hybrid learning models because of the coronavirus, one thing is clear: Screen-based instruction will be the reality for hundreds of thousands of students across the country. In addition to access issues caused by the digital divide, families must also grapple with what an increased use of devices may mean for their children’s well-being, including their vision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: Cardi B interviews Biden: ‘I just want Trump out.’
description: Cardi B, the Bronx-raised rapper known for hot summer songs and even hotter takes, remains a critical voice in politics, particularly for millennial and Gen-Z voters. She has leveraged her platform and her nearly 73 million Instagram followers to educate her young and diverse fan base on a range of issues, including the importance of getting out the vote.
content: Cardi B, the Bronx-raised rapper known for hot summer songs and even hotter takes, remains a critical voice in politics, particularly for millennial and Gen-Z voters. She has leveraged her platform and her nearly 73 million Instagram followers to educate her young and diverse fan base on a range of issues, including the importance of getting out the vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Henry Fountain
title: Trump Administration Finalizes Plan to Open Arctic Refuge to Drilling
description: The decision sets up a fierce legal battle over the fate of a vast, remote area that is home to polar bears, caribou and the promise of oil wealth.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday finalized its plan to open up part of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil and gas development, a move that overturns six decades of protections for the largest remaining stretch of wilderness in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Here’s how to watch the Democratic convention.
description: The Democratic National Convention will air from 9 p.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern time every day, Monday through Thursday.
content: The Democratic National Convention will air from 9 p.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern time every day, Monday through Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Karen Yourish
title: The president’s top donors from 2016 are not giving as much to his re-election.
description: President Trump is struggling to attract and retain a reliable stable of millionaires and billionaires willing to write seven-figure checks, despite his takeover of the Republican Party and a policy agenda that largely serves the interests of America’s ultrawealthy. Thus far, only six of the top 38 donors to Trump-related super PACs in 2016 and 2018 have contributed to America First for the president’s re-election, according to a New York Times analysis of federal campaign finance data.
content: President Trump is struggling to attract and retain a reliable stable of millionaires and billionaires willing to write seven-figure checks, despite his takeover of the Republican Party and a policy agenda that largely serves the interests of America’s ultrawealthy. Thus far, only six of the top 38 donors to Trump-related super PACs in 2016 and 2018 have contributed to America First for the president’s re-election, according to a New York Times analysis of federal campaign finance data.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside Operation Warp Speed
description: The goal of the initiative is admirable: getting a coronavirus vaccine out to Americans and saving lives as soon as possible. It is not, however, without its problems.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Cooper and Thomas Kaplan
title: Here is the Democrats’ opening night lineup.
description: Driven online, like so much of life, by the pandemic, the Democratic National Convention that is getting underway Monday night will not feature the customary cheers, boos and cascading balloon drops of yore — or, its organizers hope, the dropped Zoom calls of today.
content: Driven online, like so much of life, by the pandemic, the Democratic National Convention that is getting underway Monday night will not feature the customary cheers, boos and cascading balloon drops of yore — or, its organizers hope, the dropped Zoom calls of today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Save the Gaiters!
description: A small study prompted fears that neck gaiters could spread more virus droplets than they stop. But new research shows that those face coverings can protect just as well as other cloth masks.
content: The reports of the demise of the neck gaiter have been greatly exaggerated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Toxic Trade-Offs at Facebook
description: Facebook groups led to the rise of QAnon. We can only imagine what could happen with encryption.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hussein Mohamed and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Attack on Beachside Somalia Hotel Kills at Least 16
description: The extremist group Al Shabab has escalated assaults in recent months, even as the country confronts a host of other challenges, including containing the coronavirus.
content: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A terrorist attack on a popular hotel in the Somali capital that left at least 16 people dead, including five assailants, ended with the dramatic rescue of more than 200 people on Sunday after a raging gun battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Blue Hill at Stone Barns to Pivot to Chef-in-Residence Program
description: Neither of the chef Dan Barber’s two restaurants will reopen in their current format in 2021, nor will they continue to be called Blue Hill.
content: The Blue Hill restaurants at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., and in Greenwich Village will not reopen in their current formats next year, nor will the restaurants be called Blue Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Tens of Thousands Join Belarus Protests, Leaving Strongman Increasingly Isolated
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 17, 2020.
content: “We have woken up to the fact that we want to be free, we want to he human. The government believed that they are gods and we are nothing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Jonathan Martin
title: All the Republicans Who Have Decided Not to Support Trump
description: Numerous top G.O.P. officials have said publicly or privately that they will not be backing the president’s re-election. Here’s a look at where they stand.
content: As November draws nearer, a few current and former Republican officials have begun to break ranks with the rest of their party, saying in public and private conversations that they will not support President Trump in his re-election. Some have even said that they will be voting for his Democratic opponent, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Cooper
title: The convention’s big-tent approach strains to accommodate both John Kasich and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
description: Some of the tensions inherent in the Democrats’ big-tent approach to their convention broke into view Monday in a revealing back-and-forth between two very different politicians who will speak on behalf of Joseph R. Biden Jr.: John R. Kasich, a Republican who served as governor of Ohio and ran for president in 2016, and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, a rising Democratic star who is a favorite of the progressive left.
content: Some of the tensions inherent in the Democrats’ big-tent approach to their convention broke into view Monday in a revealing back-and-forth between two very different politicians who will speak on behalf of Joseph R. Biden Jr.: John R. Kasich, a Republican who served as governor of Ohio and ran for president in 2016, and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, a rising Democratic star who is a favorite of the progressive left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Treleaven
title: Get Ready for a Teacher Shortage Like We’ve Never Seen Before
description: If we force teachers to return to schools during an out-of-control pandemic, I don’t know how many will stick around.
content: HOUSTON — Usually on the first day back to work after summer break, there’s this buzzing, buoyant energy in the air. My school is a small school-within-a-school designated to serve gifted children, so there are only 16 teachers and staff members. We typically meet in a colleague’s tidy classroom, filled with natural light and the earthy smell of coffee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Mitra Taj
title: Struggling With Lockdown, Schools Relearn Value of Older Tech: TV
description: Poor regions across the globe where internet access is scarce are turning to television to reach students. That strategy could also help in wealthy countries that have focused on online classes.
content: In a hillside shantytown of Lima, Peru, Delia Huamani’s school day starts not with the bustle of classmates, but with the flicker of a television. With physical schools closed indefinitely, she gets her lessons at home, from the country’s brand-new library of slickly made educational broadcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Will the Democrats’ virtual convention be a flop, or must-see TV?
description: Greetings from the Democratic convention in Milwaukee!
content: Greetings from the Democratic convention in Milwaukee!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Welcome, Democrats, to Wherever It Is That We Are
description: Is Biden-Harris the answer to the confusion and sorrow of Trump’s America?
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, last week I argued that what the Republicans need this November is “the political equivalent of an unsedated colonoscopy.” Several readers, including a couple of medical professionals, wrote in to say that unsedated colonoscopies actually aren’t all that bad. (I’ll take their word for it.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Michael D. Shear and Trip Gabriel
title: Postal Crisis Has States Looking for Alternatives to Mail-In Ballots
description: A crisis of confidence in the Postal Service is pushing Democratic Party and state officials to look for a Plan B: ballot drop-boxes, curbside voting, and even expanded in-person polling sites.
content: Postal slowdowns and warnings of delayed mail-in ballots are causing election officials to rethink vote-by-mail strategies, with some states seeking to bypass the post office with ballot drop boxes, drive-through drop-offs or expanded in-person voting options, despite the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Quoctrung Bui
title: The Recession Is About to Slam Cities. Not Just the Blue-State Ones.
description: Those with budgets that rely heavily on tourism, sales taxes or direct state assistance will face particular distress.
content: The coronavirus recession will erode city budgets in many insidious ways. It will slash the casino revenues that Detroit relies on. It will squeeze the state aid that is a lifeblood to Rochester and Buffalo in upstate New York. It will cut the sales tax revenue in New Orleans and Baton Rouge, where a healthy government depends on people buying things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: ‘The Keep Going Song’ Review: The Music of Faith Under Quarantine
description: This streaming piece by Abigail and Shaun Bengson translates the agonies and ecstasies of lockdown into a cosmic hootenanny at his folks’ house.
content: One bright pleasure amid the grimness of the pandemic has been the serendipity of hearing from people you’ve lost touch with and had forgotten how much you liked. You get to learn where they’ve been sheltering in place, and how they might have been changed by this age of upheaval and displacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Reid J. Epstein
title: Milwaukee loses a mega-event: ‘No Brewers, no Bucks, no convention.’
description: MILWAUKEE — In a year of canceled plans, with vacations, graduations and sports seasons upended by the coronavirus crisis, the stretch of downtown Milwaukee where Democrats were supposed to hold their nominating convention this week was quiet and sparsely populated — another reminder of a summer lost.
content: MILWAUKEE — In a year of canceled plans, with vacations, graduations and sports seasons upended by the coronavirus crisis, the stretch of downtown Milwaukee where Democrats were supposed to hold their nominating convention this week was quiet and sparsely populated — another reminder of a summer lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: California Expresses Frustration as Blackouts Enter 4th Day
description: The agency that manages the state’s electric grid says rolling blackouts are needed to balance supply and demand. But the governor said regulators were not prepared.
content: Lawmakers and consumer groups expressed outrage on Monday that the operator of California’s electricity grid had not adequately prepared for a heat wave and was resorting to rolling blackouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Biden Heads Into Convention With Diminished but Still Sizable Lead
description: Recent polls show him with an edge of eight to nine percentage points among likely voters.
content: A wave of new national surveys shows that Joe Biden maintains a significant if slightly diminished lead over Donald J. Trump, leaving him in a stronger position to oust an incumbent president than any challenger heading into his party’s convention in the modern polling era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Luka Doncic and Kristaps Porzingis Set for N.B.A. Playoffs Debut
description: How the Dallas Mavericks’ two young European stars fare on the league’s biggest stage looms as one of the foremost curiosities of the playoffs.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — For the past several days in the N.B.A. bubble, Luka Doncic and Kristaps Porzingis have been asked various forms of the same question, occasionally with the tone of a lecture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump as Candidate: Racist Attacks, Conspiracy Theories, War on the Post Office
description: President Trump long ago redefined what constitutes normal in the White House, but with 77 days left in the campaign he is pushing all the boundaries at once.
content: How many ways are there to say that this is not normal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill canceled in-person learning a week into the semester.
content: It’s back-to-school week for large portions of the United States, and local school districts are finally putting their pandemic education plans into action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: The M.V.P.s of This Year’s Conventions? The Digital and I.T. Teams
description: Making sure livestreams don’t lag. Sending out remote video kits. Showing speakers how to avoid microphone mishaps. Digital planners for the conventions have suddenly become all-important.
content: A political convention is traditionally the work of thousands — event planners and security workers, camera operators and stage managers, handlers and groomers, even an inflation team for the ceremonial balloon drop on the nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Islamist Assault on Somali Hotel Kills at Least 15
description: The Shabab, the extremist group affiliated with Al Qaeda, claimed responsibility. It has carried many similar, deadly attacks in Somalia and neighboring Kenya.
content: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A militant attack on a beachside hotel in Somalia’s capital killed at least 15 people and wounded dozens of others on Sunday, according to police officers and a government spokesman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: Check Your Basement for Old Fishing Gear
description: It might be worth thousands at auction.
content: Ellis Whiteaker, 11, didn’t know what he might find when he went hunting in his basement in Fayetteville, N.C. But he had seen a call for fishing antiques on a social-networking app he uses (he’s been an avid fishermen since age 4) and knew that his grandfather, a former Air Force pilot who passed away before Ellis was born, had left some very old stuff in boxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Wisconsin Democrats ponder the convention that might have been.
description: This was supposed to be a banner moment for Democrats in Wisconsin, a chance to put out the welcome mat for thousands of delegates and gush about “America’s Dairyland.”
content: This was supposed to be a banner moment for Democrats in Wisconsin, a chance to put out the welcome mat for thousands of delegates and gush about “America’s Dairyland.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Traister
title: Updating the ‘You Go Girl’ Book Collection
description: New children’s books published to mark the 19th Amendment’s 100th anniversary provide a wider lens than Alice Paul and dig deeper than “Girls Rule!”
content: If you’re a parent of kids (who am I kidding: girls) and possess a passing interest in basic human rights and dignity, you most likely have been gifted some of the books I have come to call the You Go Girl Collection. Infant libraries once home mostly to overinvested bunny mothers and magic pasta pots are now studded with bobble-headed cartoon depictions of female pioneers from Ada Lovelace to Bessie Coleman, while older kids now read about women resisting, persisting and dissenting till they puke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips and Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: From a Wrestling Ring to Tiny Boxes: How ‘Chad Deity’ Went Zoom
description: Two critics square off to determine how well this body slam of a comedy, about stereotypes and storytelling, made it to the very small screen.
content: If you had to select the least likely play to translate to Zoom, it might well be Kristoffer Diaz’s “The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity.” A 2010 Pulitzer Prize finalist, the play uses the outlandish world of professional wrestling, with its larger-than-life heroes and villains and reliance on ethnic stereotypes, to consider the power of storytelling itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Chaat Is More Than the Sum of Its Many Flavors
description: Hard to define but easy to crave, these Indian snacks have become a fascination for the Nashville chef Maneet Chauhan.
content: The chef Maneet Chauhan likes to think of chaat as an emotion. A single bite can be jolting, pucker-inducing and refreshing all at once, balancing sweet with salty, tangy with spicy, crunchy with creamy, demanding you come back for more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Toronto Police to Pay $12.5 Million to Protesters Arrested During 2010 G-20 Summit
description: Brutal police tactics during the global meeting shocked many Canadians, led to 1,100 arrests and were found unlawful.
content: As world leaders gathered in Toronto a decade ago they were at first met by largely peaceful demonstrators pressing for action on climate change, and Indigenous and gay rights. But a small group of protesters smashed windows, looted shops and burned police cars in the main shopping district​.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Is Herd Immunity Ahead of Schedule?
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Today, we’re turning this section over to our colleague Apoorva Mandavilli, who has been covering the pandemic for The Times’s Science desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Raymond Zhong
title: Trump Administration Widens Huawei Dragnet
description: The Commerce Department placed new restrictions on the Chinese tech giant’s ability to work with the global chip industry.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration announced on Monday that it was restricting Huawei’s ability to buy a wider array of chips made or designed with American equipment and software, tightening the limits it has placed on the Chinese telecom giant as it looks to cripple its ability to sell smartphones and telecom gear around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: From ‘Proud Family’ to ‘The Boondocks’: 11 Black Animated Series
description: These shows serve up rich depictions of Black families that don’t fall into stereotype, while taking some insider shots (sorry, Tyler Perry).
content: If the last few months have taught us anything, it’s that the time for representation is yesterday — and that people are willing to make public calls for change. But undoing years of messaging about the irrelevance of Black lives and voices isn’t easy. The TV and film industry, in particular, has been slow to include Black characters that don’t fall into racist stereotypes. (Yes, Disney archives, I’m looking at you.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Defendant’s Luck Runs Out. But the Lucky Phone Number Fetches $325,000.
description: The Chinese phone number, ending in five 8s, drew 5,000 bids because it’s considered auspicious. Such phone numbers are coveted status symbols in China.
content: HONG KONG — The defendant wasn’t so lucky. But one fortunate bidder is hoping the person’s phone number will be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Moving to New York, Despite the Pandemic
description: A retired nurse from Pennsylvania, she had wanted to move to Manhattan since she was a child. So when the coronavirus hit, she came anyway.
content: Cynthia Lanzino wanted to move to New York City ever since she was a child growing up in Pennsylvania. So this spring, Ms. Lanzino, 63, decided not to wait any longer. Even if there was a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.N.C. at Chapel Hill Shifts to Remote Learning After a Covid-19 Outbreak
description: The virus is roaring again in France. Louis DeJoy, the U.S. postmaster general, agreed to testify before the House Oversight Committee on Aug. 24.
content: As teachers and students look ahead to the start of the school year, officials around the world continued this week to roll out and refine strategies to address the challenges and fears brought on by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The Week Old Hollywood Finally, Actually Died
description: The streaming services are in charge, and bringing a ruthless new culture with them.
content: For decades, the best thing about being a Hollywood executive, really, was how you got fired. Studio executives would be gradually, gently, even lovingly, nudged aside, given months to shape their own narratives and find new work, or even promoted. When Amy Pascal was pushed out of Sony Pictures in 2015, she got an exit package and production deal worth a reported $40 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: I Asked Bernie Sanders if It Was All Over. ‘No,’ He Groaned.
description: The senator from Vermont explains why the left still has a fighting chance.
content: I have said goodbye to Bernie Sanders before. There was the parting pageantry of the 2016 Democratic Convention where Mr. Sanders conceded the nomination to Hillary Clinton, closing out a primary season so tight it had given even the most pessimistic of leftists a thrill of hope. As he called for unity against Donald Trump in his farewell, the news network’s camera found a crying 22-year-old Bernie delegate in a Robin Hood hat, and the internet tore him apart. Laugh it up, I thought; there will be a next time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Final Battleground in the Fight for Suffrage
description: On Aug. 18, 1920, a young state legislator listened to his mama, and Tennessee became the final state to ratify the 19th Amendment.
content: NASHVILLE — Tuesday marks 100 years since the Tennessee General Assembly voted to ratify the 19th Amendment, which gave American women the right to vote and shifted the national political landscape as thoroughly as any earthquake, tornado, and tidal wave combined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Outbreaks Drive U.N.C. Chapel Hill Online After a Week of Classes
description: The university chose to abandon in-person instruction for undergraduates after at least 177 students tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: ATLANTA — Citing an “untenable situation” caused by a spike in coronavirus cases after the first week of classes, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill said on Monday that it would shut down in-person instruction for undergraduates and move entirely online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Is Accused of Spying for China
description: The arrest of a 67-year-old Hawaii resident is the latest case involving former intelligence officers charged with providing classified documents to Beijing.
content: WASHINGTON — A former C.I.A. officer was charged with giving classified information to the Chinese government, the Justice Department announced on Monday, the latest in a string of former intelligence officers accused of spying for Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: With Simona Halep Out, U.S. Open Field Is Missing Many Top Women
description: Serena Williams, Naomi Osaka and Sofia Kenin remain, giving the New York event plenty of star power and interesting story lines.
content: This will be the most unusual United States Open in history, with no spectators, an all-but-empty Arthur Ashe Stadium and players following extensive health and safety guidelines because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: U.S. Tries to Bolster Taiwan’s Status, Short of Recognizing Sovereignty
description: President Trump prefers a robust relationship with authoritarian China to one with democratic Taiwan. But other American officials aim to strengthen U.S.-Taiwan ties.
content: WASHINGTON — A visit to Taiwan by an American cabinet secretary. A sale of advanced torpedoes. Talk of starting negotiations over a potential trade agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Contact Lenses May Slow Nearsightedness in Children
description: Children who wore high-power bifocal contacts had less worsening of myopia.
content: Wearing bifocal contact lenses may slow the progression of nearsightedness in children, a new study in JAMA suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: New Zealand Election Delayed Amid New Coronavirus Outbreak
description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said the September national election would be postponed by four weeks, citing voter safety and a lockdown in Auckland that would make it difficult to campaign.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — New Zealand on Monday said it would postpone its national election by four weeks as a cluster of new coronavirus cases continued to spread through the city of Auckland despite a lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: ‘I Was Selling Honey to Survive.’ Then Mel Gibson Threatened to Sue.
description: A single mother in Chile began selling organic honey from home during quarantine, using the actor’s name as a play on words. His lawyer was not amused.
content: It was a venture born of desperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Lizzo Notches a Win in ‘Truth Hurts’ Copyright Case
description: A judge ruled that just because a group of songwriters worked on one “DNA test” song with Lizzo doesn’t mean they have a claim to another.
content: A federal judge has handed a victory to Lizzo, the Grammy-winning R&B and pop star, in a bitter fight over copyright and songwriting credit in Lizzo’s breakthrough hit, “Truth Hurts.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: TikTok Makes a Deal (Not That One)
description: As the Chinese-owned app negotiates its potential sale, it is signing a different sort of deal.
content: Today, we start with a scoop about TikTok, the video-sharing app that’s caught in the middle of the U.S.-China tech war. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: What if ‘Herd Immunity’ Is Closer Than Scientists Thought?
description: In what may be the world’s most important math puzzle, researchers are trying to figure out how many people in a community must be immune before the coronavirus fades.
content: We’ve known from the beginning how the end will arrive. Eventually, the coronavirus will be unable to find enough susceptible hosts to survive, fading out wherever it briefly emerges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Fessler
title: The Power of Low-Stakes Productivity
description: The smaller the better.
content: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, we email readers tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Ending a Mystery, Spain Says Ex-King Is in U.A.E.
description: The former monarch, Juan Carlos, said this month that he would be leaving his country amid a series of investigations related to his wealth.
content: Spain’s royal household said on Monday that the former king, Juan Carlos, was in the United Arab Emirates, two weeks after he left Spain for an unknown destination amid investigations relating to his personal wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: New York Has Tamed the Virus. Can It Hold Off a Second Wave?
description: The sustained low rate of infection has surprised local health officials. But a resurgence may be inevitable, despite the state’s and city’s best efforts.
content: Health experts in New York City thought that coronavirus cases would be rising again by now. Their models predicted it. They were wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion’s Raunchy ‘WAP’ Rockets to No. 1
description: The rappers’ single debuts at the top of Billboard’s Hot 100 while Taylor Swift earns a third consecutive week leading the Top 200.
content: Taylor Swift dominates the Billboard album chart once again this week, while Cardi B lands perhaps the raunchiest No. 1 single in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Beaten Back, the Coronavirus Regains Strength in France
description: Faced with an increase in infections, especially among young adults, French health officials are expanding mask rules and warning against complacence.
content: PARIS — As the two women sat in deck chairs enjoying the last rays of sunshine near the Canal de l’Ourcq in Paris on Sunday evening, nearby loudspeakers jolted them with a reminder that they were in a new mask-mandatory zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annalee Newitz
title: Want to Flee the City for Suburbia? Think Again
description: The 20th century is full of examples of the false promise of suburban living.
content: Walking the streets of San Francisco during these coronavirus days, you’ll see a sight rarer than Bigfoot: “for sale” and “for rent” signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Doug Emhoff, Kamala Harris’s husband, takes a leave of absence from his law firm.
description: Kamala Harris’s husband, Douglas C. Emhoff, has taken a leave of absence from the international law firm DLA Piper, a law firm spokesman said Monday evening, confirming a development first reported by The American Lawyer.
content: Kamala Harris’s husband, Douglas C. Emhoff, has taken a leave of absence from the international law firm DLA Piper, a law firm spokesman said Monday evening, confirming a development first reported by The American Lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: N.Y. Gyms and Fitness Studios Can Reopen as Soon as Aug. 24, Cuomo Says
description: Health clubs will be limited to a third of their total capacity and must meet state requirements before reopening, the governor said.
content: Gyms in New York, which have remained shuttered for months even as the state made progress in fighting the coronavirus, will be allowed to open again as soon as Aug. 24 and no later than Sept. 2, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Alan Blinder
title: What to Know About the Pac-12 in the Fall
description: Monday: California is influencing pandemic plans for conferences nationwide. Also: A heat wave hits the state.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Are Student Newspapers Covering Back to School?
description: We want to hear how student journalists are approaching this unusual school year.
content: Are you a reporter at a college or high school paper? We’d love to hear from you about how you’re planning your first few weeks of coverage. What are the obstacles? What has surprised you? We may feature some responses in the Coronavirus Schools Briefing in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: John Kasich, a ‘Deeply Worried’ Republican, Steps Up for Biden
description: John R. Kasich, a lifelong Republican and former rival of President Trump’s spoke at the Democratic convention — and says he will vote for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: Former Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, the last candidate standing against Donald J. Trump for the Republican nomination four years ago, crossed the partisan divide on Monday night to speak at the Democratic National Convention and call on fellow Republicans to abandon the president in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haider Warraich
title: Covid-19 Is Creating a Wave of Heart Disease
description: Emerging data show that some of the coronavirus’s most potent damage is inflicted on the heart.
content: SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19, was initially thought to primarily impact the lungs — SARS stands for “severe acute respiratory syndrome.” Now we know there is barely a part of the body this infection spares. And emerging data show that some of the virus’s most potent damage is inflicted on the heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Sorry, the World’s Biggest Bike Maker Can’t Help You Buy a Bike Right Now
description: The pandemic has created a bicycle boom — and a shortage. Giant, the Taiwanese juggernaut, is trying to meet demand while navigating the politics of trade.
content: TAICHUNG, Taiwan — Because gyms are closed and we could all use a little more exercise; because we are avoiding buses and trains; because we are in need of outdoor group activities; or perhaps just because the pandemic has made us crave simple pleasures like the wind against our faces, bicycle sales are soaring around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Retreats in a U.K. Exam Debacle
description: With students unable to sit for college exams during the pandemic, the government tried guessing how they might do. It did not go well.
content: LONDON — Barraged by protests from angry teachers, parents and students, the British government has abandoned the improvised college-entrance exam system it cobbled together for schools in England after the pandemic made traditional testing impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Malin
title: What Actually Happens When a TV Episode Gets Pulled?
description: This summer brought a flurry of TV takedowns, with offensive episodes of “30 Rock,” “Workaholics” and others being removed from circulation. But in the digital era, what does that even mean?
content: This has been takedown summer for television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr
title: The Conventions Are Starting. Cue the Virtual Excitement.
description: Here’s what you need to know about the unconventional conventions.
content: [The Democratic National Convention Guide: Speakers, Start Time, Schedule and More.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A College’s ‘Free Speech Areas’ Face Supreme Court Review
description: The justices will consider whether a student’s First Amendment lawsuit may proceed after a college in Georgia abandoned its restrictions.
content: WASHINGTON — A few years ago, a college student in Georgia stood on a stool outside a campus food court to talk about his Christian faith. He spoke for 20 minutes about human frailty and the possibility of salvation when school officials told him he had to stop or face discipline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Marvin Creamer, a Mariner Who Sailed Like the Ancients, Dies at 104
description: No GPS for him, not even a sextant; the sun and the stars did nicely. He was the first recorded person to sail round the world without navigational instruments.
content: Had Marvin Creamer not been a geographer, he very likely would not have lived to be 104.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 17, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 17, 2020.
content: Because of a production error, an obituary about Robert S. Trump, President Trump’s younger brother, was missing from some editions of Sunday’s paper. It is reprinted today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: Families Are Central to Critical Care. But the Waiting Room Is Empty.
description: Family members play an important role in the care we provide. I miss them.
content: One morning in early March, during what would be our last week of normalcy, my team gathered outside our patient’s room on morning rounds. The beleaguered overnight intern began to present the details of the case. Then stopped. We needed to wait. The patient’s wife was on the way — and we couldn’t start without her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Barbara Caplan, Spotter of Consumer Trends, Dies at 93
description: After raising a family, she got a master’s degree in psychology and became an expert in what people would crave and buy. She tested positive for Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
title: Trump says he plans to deliver his acceptance speech at the White House.
description: President Trump confirmed Monday that he will deliver his own nomination acceptance speech next week at the White House, telling a small crowd in Wisconsin that he will “have plenty to say” as he formally becomes the Republican candidate for his re-election.
content: President Trump confirmed Monday that he will deliver his own nomination acceptance speech next week at the White House, telling a small crowd in Wisconsin that he will “have plenty to say” as he formally becomes the Republican candidate for his re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Convention Kicks Off
description: Who will be watching and what’s on tap?
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Giovanni Russonello, typically the morning newsletter writer. I’ll be your evening host during the conventions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: What Historical Moment Is Leon Neyfakh Learning From Now?
description: The creators of “Slow Burn” have a new season of their podcast “Fiasco,” which looks at the yearslong fight over school desegregation in Boston.
content: In 2017, the first season of Leon Neyfakh’s podcast, “Slow Burn,” retold the story of the Watergate scandal, unearthing key details and subjecting them to close analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
title: No Longer Cowed, Belarus Has Message for Once-Mighty Dictator: ‘Go Away!’
description: As even his base starts to desert him after protests over a rigged election were met with brutality, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s 26-year grip on power may be slipping.
content: MINSK, Belarus — In an age of ascendant strongman leaders, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus is suddenly looking surprisingly weak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert, Cora Engelbrecht, Oleg Matsnev and A.J. Chavar
title: A Crackdown in Belarus Backfires. Here’s What Videos Show.
description: Protests took a decisive turn last week after videos of security officers brutally repressing demonstrators were widely shared.
content: [Read more on what’s happening in Belarus: protests, police and government.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: If a Dunk Echoes Across an Empty Gym, Is It Still Must-See TV?
description: Fans have long been prized by leagues for their big spending on tickets and overpriced beer. Now, amid the pandemic, spectators deserve appreciation for making sports entertaining.
content: Sports went away and then returned to empty arenas during the past five months of the coronavirus pandemic, pushing fans ever further to the periphery of professional sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, Paul Mozur and Raymond Zhong
title: Trump’s Attacks on TikTok and WeChat Could Further Fracture the Internet
description: The president’s restrictions on Chinese tech may be part of an eye-for-an-eye logic called reciprocity. The price could be a global patchwork of online fiefs.
content: WASHINGTON — China and the United States once acted like opposites when it came to governing the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: When The Times Opposed Women’s Suffrage
description: I am not proud of all my predecessors’ views.
content: When Tennessee became the 36th state to ratify women’s suffrage, one hundred years ago on Tuesday, many American women saw the realization of a dream deferred since the country’s founding: They could have a hand in shaping democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Israeli Jets Arrive for 1st Joint Military Exercises on German Soil
description: Germany is aiming to modernize its armed forces, even as it struggles with signs of far-right extremism in its ranks. Israel will benefit from NATO techniques and new terrain.
content: SASSNITZ, Germany — Israeli fighter jets on Monday landed in Germany for the first time, in a display of the two countries’ strong ties more than 75 years after the end of the Nazi Holocaust and as the German military is struggling with signs of rising far-right sentiment in its ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Europe’s Big Oil Companies Are Turning Electric
description: Under pressure from governments and investors, industry leaders like BP and Shell are accelerating their production of cleaner energy.
content: This may turn out to be the year that oil giants, especially in Europe, started looking more like electric companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Puerto Rico’s governor lost her primary bid for a full term.
description: Gov. Wanda Vázquez of Puerto Rico conceded defeat on Sunday night to Pedro R. Pierluisi, a former congressional representative who briefly served as the island’s governor last year.
content: Gov. Wanda Vázquez of Puerto Rico conceded defeat on Sunday night to Pedro R. Pierluisi, a former congressional representative who briefly served as the island’s governor last year.

description: “We have to vote for the right people. And then we have to hold our leaders accountable,” the philanthropist said.
content: — Melinda Gates, co-chair of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation

title: Fry With Me
description: There’s nothing like crisp fried foods at the height of summer: Start with pea kachori, then move into fried artichokes, tostones, even French fries.
content: Good morning! It’s Monday, in case you need a reminder, and this is Tejal, filling in for Sam.

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Japan’s Economy Contracts 7.8 Percent, Worst Decline on Record
description: The quarterly slide, an annualized drop of 27.8 percent, coincides with a long and uncertain road to recovery.
content: TOKYO — Japan’s economy shrank 7.8 percent in the second quarter of the year, its worst performance on record, as the coronavirus pandemic ground economic activity to a near halt in April and May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Cuomo Announces Guidelines for Reopening New York Gyms
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced that gyms and fitness studios in New York could reopen as soon as Aug. 24, and would be limited to a third of their total capacity.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced that gyms and fitness studios in New York could reopen as soon as Aug. 24, and would be limited to a third of their total capacity.

author: By Reuters
title: Federal Prosecutor Announces Charges in Jam Master Jay Case
description: The acting U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York said two men have been charged in the 2002 killing of Jason Mizell, also known as Jam Master Jay from the group Run-DMC.
content: The acting U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York said two men have been charged in the 2002 killing of Jason Mizell, also known as Jam Master Jay from the group Run-DMC.

title: Washington National Zoo Could Gain a New Baby Panda
description: A 22-year-old giant panda at the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington appears to be pregnant and could give birth to a cub in a few days.

title: New Zealand’s Prime Minister Delays Election as Virus Cases Spread
description: On Monday, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand announced that the September election would be delayed by four weeks as new virus cases spread across Auckland.
